ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: So much about the political economy of infrastructure and the role that race, dispossession, displacement, and much more plays into infrastructure. What is infrastructure and what infrastructure can be, what structures our contemporary infrastructures, critical race theory and Indigenous history. How to read better, how to write better.

I learned about the development of infrastructure throughout history and how it affected the many different populations that inhabit the United States. We discussed how different kinds of development both affected the landscape and human components of the country, and the modern implications.

GREAT CLASS. I learned so much about US history through an infrastructural lens. We learned about the physical, social, political, and economic levels of infrastructure projects, and the ongoing impact on the country!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: The readings were so good. Like I kid you not they went crazy week after week. The discussion was very good and helped bring out key parts of the readings. No the readings were so good. Also thematically the course was constructed clearly to incorporate the politics of infrastructure, like Indigenous displacement and anti-Black structural racism, which are central. This courses asks you to think critically about infrastructure, who makes it, why it's made, and how that affects people.

Weaknesses: I don't like 19th century rail stuff and those histories are always really technical so that week was kinda eh, although it's important to be able to read those so it was fine. The person who wanted to colonize Greenland in the course should've been approached with more...criticism... specifically because it was just such in opposition to the course themes!! There is a substantial focus on writing itself, which should have made the course a Writing Credit, but it wasn't. Tragic. 

This isn't a "weakness" per say but I wish there was like another version of the course that touched on many of the infrastructures we didn't talk about (just simply because of time limits), and even Prof Rose acknowledged this as well. Things like public murals/art, oil platforms, natural gas lines, the nuclear family, boats, planes, airports, marinas, schools, broadband/cable networks, sewage/plumbing + water towers; food, food deserts, and grocery stores; schools; hospitals and healthcare, satellites, and so much more would be awesome too.

The readings were very interesting, and definitely the heart of the course. There were a lot of readings at first so it was hard to spend enough time on them to fully digest them, but lessening them at the mid semester mark helped solve that problem. The discussions were also always lively and interesting.  Feedback on my writing from Professor Rose was also one of the best parts of the class, and will help me in my coming semesters.

Strengths: read a wide array of texts and plenty of room for discussion, appreciated the inclusion of Indigenous perspectives and other marginalized voices when they could be found

Weaknesses: reading load was initially extremely high (but reduced by the professor mid-semester after feedback), as with most US history/history courses the syllabus included a lot of white men, and certainly could be improved by including more diverse voices or revisionist histories, professor accommodated some student comments that several students found over the line re. colonialism, lots of writing for not being a writing credit

Strength: Taylor is awesome and can lead a discussion like very few other professors I've had. The readings were all super interesting and offered nuanced takes on multiple subjects. Taylor also gives great, specific, essay feedback. 

Weakness: The readings were often a bit too long, but interesting nonetheless.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely. Absolutely. Absolutely. Excellent choice of readings, productive discussion, challenging assignments, intensive feedback.
Yes I would wholeheartedly recommend this course to another student! It was interesting, engaging, and I learned a lot.
Yes! Normally I feel a bit anxious going into seminar classes, but I was always genuinely excited for this class.
